Abstract: Avraham Biran, an archaeologist who was born 90 years ago in Galilee highlands, says Palestinians do not relate to the land the way Jews do, but he predicts that there will be a Palestinian state, even in his lifetime, and that Israel will endure for hundreds of years; Ayman Abu-Shirbi, 13-year-old Palestinian, sees his future as a scientist and citizen of Palestine; photos; chronology of Palestine's history since 1916 (M)
Snippet: Avraham Biran, an archaeologist who was born 90 years ago in Galilee highlands, says Palestinians do not relate to the land the way Jews do, but he predicts that there will be a Palestinian state, even in his lifetime, and that Israel will endure ...
LeadParagraph: Avraham Biran, 90, and Ayman Abu-Shirbi, 13, define themselves through scholarship. A second-generation descendant of the earliest Zionist pioneers, Dr. Biran grew up under Ottoman rule in Rosh Pina, a village in the Galilee highlands founded by his Romanian great-grandparents. One of Israel's pre-eminent archaeologists, he has spent most of his life connecting the Israel of today to the Israel of the Bible.

Headline.Main: REFLECTIONS: ISRAEL AND WEST BANK; 'As an Archaeologist, I Have Seen Too Many Destructions'
Headline.PrintHeadline: REFLECTIONS: ISRAEL AND WEST BANK; 'As an Archaeologist, I Have Seen Too Many Destructions'
